posts.name: Vivi S
posts.cooked:
Hi! My team is currently in the process of redesigning our Driver Station and I was wondering‚Ä¶

What is one (or multiple) things you HAVE to have on your DS ? This isn‚Äôt going by the game manual or anything, just things that has made your team‚Äôs life 1000x easier.

And also, what are your DS made of? Our old one is made of wood, which has splintered and broken apart really badly over the last few years.

Thanks!

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
If the DS laptop you are using have rj45, get yourself a ethernet pigtail.

image 970√ó728 32 KB

image 970√ó728 32 KB

image 970√ó728 32 KB

This will save your port so you don‚Äôt get disconnected on the field because of a bad port.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked:
Nice to have it fit through a standard door in the usual orientation (especially if on your cart). Secure everything down - we have our gamepad in a secure cradle, the joystick is bolted down, and the laptop has a lot of velcro on the underside. Still haven‚Äôt figured out how to manage the laptop power cord though.

Ours is built mostly out of HDPE.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Ian2
posts.cooked:
We collected that must have, nice to have, and resulting output for us last year over here: Driver Station in a Box

Perhaps a silly / obvious one: you‚Äôll need a computer that runs windows for the Driver Station application. That one is per rules.

posts.name: Ian2
posts.cooked: Paraphrasing from @ngreen in that thread because I don‚Äôt remember if it is in the doc, velcro (hook and loop tape) to interface with the surface on the field‚Äôs Driver Station shelf. Nobody wants to start their important match playing catch the Driver Station.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
A driver station is first and foremost a functional object. Prioritize function over form.

How does it get to the event?

Where does it live in the pit?

How does it get to the field?

Who has to set it up?

How does it interface with the field?

How does it aid (and not distract or encumber) drivers?

How does it perform its job error free (battery life, cable connections, computer settings, mechanical robustness)?

Where does it live in the shop?

posts.name: Abdullah Khaled
posts.cooked: You might also want to consider long (but not too long) USB cords for your gamepads; no one wants to be hunched over because someone used the shortest cable they could find for the DS . Also if any rambunctious drivers hit the DS wall, nothing will get unplugged.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: I speak for the trees, not for my team.

posts.custom_user_title: I speak for the trees, not for my team.

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked: It needs to be labeled operator console. Nobody should be calling at driver station which is the place you stand next to the field.

posts.name: Charlie shaw
posts.cooked: Ours is made out of a rolling tool box.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
The laptop end of the cable must not move relative to the laptop to save the laptop port - that is: securely fasten the cable or far end connector of the cable to the solid console the laptop is on. (This does assume that the laptop isn‚Äôt going to fall off of the console; that‚Äôs another suggestion herein.)

[We have one laptop that has a USB-Ethernet dongle since when we finally figured out how to unplug the Ethernet cable the port no longer worked.]

posts.name: Jacob Weinberg
posts.cooked: Ours is in a pelican case. Or I should say both of ours are in pelican cases because backups are important. Then don‚Äôt just secure your case to the shelf but then also secure your laptop and other devices to the case. Lastly make sure you have space for wires to be put in easily and quickly (ie. no winding just a big enough are to hold the wires in  separate piles).

We are also redesigning our DS , I would say make sure it is less that 36‚Äù wide, or the width of a standard doorway in your region. It‚Äôs a lot nicer to be able to set your DS on the robot cart and push everything around.

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked:
Here are some photos of the drivers stations we built in 2023 and are still using.

IMG_1720 1279√ó959 350 KB

IMG_1720 1279√ó959 350 KB

IMG_1720 1279√ó959 350 KB

Like many others we have an ethernet pigtail that we plug into so we aren‚Äôt wearing out the port on the laptop. We also have a USB hub and two panel mount USB extensions that we plug the controllers into. There is a 3 outlet short extension cable that sticks out the back for plugging in in the pit and at the field.

The overall width is 27‚Äù which allows it to sit on the robot cart and fit through standard doorways. On the left and right sides there is Alcobra telescoping box tubing for mounting accessories such as displays or cameras.

Here is the CAD.

link_counts.title: Aluminum Pre-Drilled Telescoping Square Tubing - .110" - Alcobra Metals

posts.name: Vivi S
posts.cooked: That looks awesome! May I ask what type of material it was built of? I was looking into HDPE but it‚Äôs quite expensive.

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked:
Most of it is bent 5052 aluminum. The top cover that opens up for access to the wiring underneath is made from polycarbonate.

The first two we built in 2023 we manufactured in house, this spring we paid about $700 for Fabworks to manufacture two more sets of sheet metal.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
We also install one of these on the robot. There is a version that fits in a round hole that may be easier to use for teams without access to a CNC router.

We used 1x2 (3/4‚Äù x 1 1/2‚Äù actual) clear pine for the frame with 1/8‚Äù polycarbonate top and bottom pieces. The two end pieces are 3/16‚Äù polycarbonate with cutouts that serve as handles.

The laptop charger is contained in one of the spaces between the top and bottom. The power cord and the ethernet cable exit through a large hole in one end. The power cord and ethernet cable can be stored inside by pushing them into the hole.

We 3D printed two holders for the controllers and included a removable panel that can serve as a button board.
